list.item: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 3 of the "TEI in Libraries Guidelines."
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Print page headers and side descriptions are not included.
OCR successfully reproduced simple tables, but complex tabular data is not captured dependably and the results should not be relied upon.
OCR was not able to successfully reproduce math and chemical formulas. The uncorrected results remain in the text.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, smallcaps, strikethrough, subscript, superscript, underline. The following print styles are ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze using machine-learning methods.

Subject keywords are added to teiHeader for each entry; they were generated by the HIVE2 automated vocabulary server, created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: This release reproduces the text matter for all entries. It does not include images, front- or back-matter. The reproduction of tables and formulae is unreliable.

div.p:
TINAMOU, the name given in Guiana to a certain bird as stated in 1741 by Barrere {FranceEquinoxiale, p. 138), from whom it was taken and used in a more general sense by Buffon {Hist. Nat.Oiseaux, iv. p. 502). In 1783 Latham {Synopsis, ii. p. 724) adopted it as English, and in 1790 {Index, ii. p. 633) Latinized it Tinarnus, as the name of a new and distinct genus. The “Tinamou” of Barrere has been identified with the “Macucagua” described and figured By Marcgrave in 1648, and is the Tinarnus major of modern authors.
Brisson and after him Linnaeus confounded this bird, which they had never seen, with the Trumpeter (g.v.).

Buffon and his successors saw that the Tinamous, though passing among the European colonists of South America as “Partridges,” could not be associated with those birds, and Latham’s step, above mentioned, was generally approved. The genus he had founded was usually placed among the Gallinae, and by many writers was held to be allied to the Bustards, which, it must be remembered, were then thought to be “Struthious.” Indeed the likeness of the Tinamou’s bili to that of the Rhea (vol. xx. p. 506) was remarked in 1811 by liliger. On the other hand L’ Herminier in 1827 saw features in the Tinamou’s sternum that in his judgment linked the bird to the Rallidae. In 1830 Wagler {Nat. Syst.Amphibien, &c., p. 127) placed the Tinamous in the same Order as the Ostrich and its allies; and, though he did this on very insufficient grounds, his assignment has turned out to be not far from the mark, as in 1862 the great affinity of these groups was shown by Prof. Parker’s researches, which were afterwards printed in the Zoological Transactions (v. pp. 205-232, 236-238, pls. xxxix.-xli.), and was further substantiated by him in the Philosophical Transactions (1866, pp. 174-178, pl. xv.). Shortly after this Prof. Huxley in his often-quoted paper in the Zoological Proceedings (1867, pp. 425, 426)
was enabled to place the whole matter in a clear light, urging that the Tinamous formed a very distinct group of birds which, though not to be removed from the Carinatae, presented so much resemblance to the Ratitae as to indicate them to be the bond of union between those two great divisions.
Μ. Alix also has from an independent investigation of the osteology and myology of Nοthwrα major come to virtually the same conclusion (Journ. deZoologie, iii. pp. 169 and 252, pls. viii.-xi.). The group from the resemblance of its palatal characters to those of the Emeu (vol. viii. p. 171), Dromaeus, he called Drcnnaeognathae, and his decision, if not his name, has since been widely accepted.

The Tinamous thus—by whatever name we call them, Dromaeognathae, Tinami, or Crypturi— will be seen to be of great importance from a taxonomer’s point of view, though in regard to numbers they are comparatively insignificant. In 1873 Messrs. Sclater and Salvin in their Nomenclator (pp. 152, 153) recognized nine genera and thirty-nine species, since which time about half a dozen other species may have been described; but in 1880 Schlegel (Mus. Pays-Bas, viii., Monogr. 41, pp. 1-51) would only admit five genera and thirty-one species—the latter because it was the number possessed by the Leyden museum. They are peculiar to the Neotropical Region—four species only finding their way into southern Mexico and none beyond. Some of them inhabit forests and others the more open country; but setting aside size (which in this group varies from that of a Quail to that of a large common Fowl) there is an unmistakable uniformity of appearance among them as a whole, so that almost anybody having seen one species of the group would always recognize another. Yet in minor characters there is considerable difference among them; and first of all the group may be divided into two sub-families, the first, Tinaminae, having four toes, and the second, Tinamotidinae, having but three—the latter containing, so far as is known, but two genera, Calopezus and Tiηamotis, each consisting of a single species, while the former, according to Messrs. Sclater and Salvin (ui supra), may be separated into seven genera, two being Tinarnus and Nothoceτcus, characterized by the roughness of their posterior tarsal scales, the others, Cryplwrus, Rhynchotus, Nothoρrocta, Nothura, and Taoηiscus, having smooth legs.

To the ordinary spectator Tinamous have much the look of Partridges, but the more attentive observer will notice that their elongated bill, their small head and slender neck, clothed with very short feathers, give them a different air. The plumage is generally inconspicuous: some tint of brown, ranging from rufous to slaty, and often more or less closely barred with a darker shade or black, is the usual style of coloration; but some species are characterized by a white throat or a bay breast. The wings are short and rounded, and in some forms the feathers of the tail, which in all are hidden by their coverts, are soft. In bearing and gait the birds show some resemblance to their distant relatives the Ratitae, and Mr

Bartlett shows (Proc. Zool. Society, 1868, p. 115, pl. xii.) that this is especially seen in the newly-hatched young. He also notices the still stronger Ratite character, that the male takes on himself the duty of incubation. The eggs are very remarkable objects, curiously unlike those of other birds; and, as before stated (Birds, vol. iii. p. 775), their shell
Herr von Nathusius has described its microscopic structure (Journ. för wissensch.Zoologie, 1871, pp. 330-355). looks as if it were of highíy-bumished metal or glazed porcelain, presenting also various colours, which seem to be constant in the particular species, from pale primrose to sage-green or light indigo, or from chocolatebrown to* pinkish orange. All who have eaten it declare the flesh of the Tinamou to have a most delicate taste, as it has a most inviting appearance, the pectoral muscles being semi-opaque. Of their habits not much has been told. Darwin (Journal, chap, iii.) has remarked upon the silliness they show in allowing themselves to be taken, and this is wholly in accordance with what Prof. Parker observes of their brain capacity, and is an additional testimony to their low morphological rank. At least one species of Tinamou has bred not unfrequently in confinement, and an interesting account of what would have been a successful attempt by Mr John Bateman to naturalize this species, Rhynchotusrufescens, in England, at Brightlingsea in Essex, appeared in The Field (23d Feb. 1884 and 12th Sept. 1885). The experiment unfortunately failed owing to the destruction of the birds by foxes. (a. n.)
